Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: It is well-settled law in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts that custody orders may be modified upon a showing of a substantial and material change in circumstances that affects the best interests of the children (Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985)).
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion in Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas concerns an initial divorce judgment determining custody and a request to remove the children to Greece; it does not address the standard for *modifying* an existing custody order. The quoted pages discuss the ‘best interests’ and ‘real advantage’ standards for removal under G.L. c. 208, § 30, not the requirement of a ‘substantial and material change in circumstances’ to alter a prior custody judgment. Thus, the case is being cited for a modification principle it does not articulate.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents who is a native of . . . this commonwealth . . . shall not, if of suitable age to signify his consent, be removed out of this commonwealth without such consent, or, if under that age, without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815)…”}
